data.title: Hiking in the Columbia River Gorge: A Complete Guide
data.meta_description: Looking to do one of the many hikes in the Columbia River Gorge? This guide to hiking in the Gorge has all the information you need to hit the trail.
data.text:
Disclaimer: Some of the links in this post, like hotel links, are affiliate links, meaning at no additional cost to you, we make a little bit of money if you click through and book. That being said, we would never recommend something to you that we donât stand behind 100%.

What to Know Before You Head Out to the Gorge

Before we get into the hikes themselves, a few things to know before you hit the hiking trails out in the Gorge.

For hikes in Washington State Parks (like Beacon Rock or Hamilton Mountain), youâll need a Discover Pass, which is the Washington State Parks pass.

It comes in either a day pass ($10) or an annual pass ($30), which means itâs worth buying if you think youâll make three visits to Washington State Parks in the next 12 months.

You can either buy it onsite at the park, or in advance from the official website (takes longer) or at REI (can do in-store pickup or shipping).

For hikes on National Forest land (like Wahclella Falls or Dry Creek Falls), you need a Northwest Forest Pass.

It is $5 for a day use permit, or $30 for an annual pass that is good for 12 months. For what itâs worth, this is the pass we

use most often. Some trailheads have either day use envelopes or a QR code where you can buy a day pass on arrival, but weâve seen plenty of times where the envelopes were out or the internet didnât work, so weâd buy it in advance at REI (either a day pass or an annual pass) if you can.

If youâre planning on visiting three or more national parks in the next 12 months, itâs worth buying an America the Beautiful Pass instead, which covers all national recreation land including national forests and national monuments (buy it at REI here).

The Best Hikes in the Columbia River Gorge: A Complete Guide

As weâve spent more time out in the Gorge, weâve realized that the Oregon side of the Gorge and the Washington side of the Gorge are completely different beasts.

The Oregon side is where youâll find the lush evergreen forests and towering waterfalls â which is usually the first thing people think of when they think of the Gorge.

So many waterfalls, in fact, that we have an entirely separate guide dedicated to waterfalls in the Columbia River Gorge!

The Washington side gets more sun, and the hikes on that side of the Gorge tend to be more about the sweeping views up and down the Gorge.

In the guide below, weâre going to indicate which side â the Oregon side and the Washington side â the hike is on within the title (e.g. âORâ or âWAâ). Weâre ordering the hikes by side of the Gorge (hikes in Oregon first, then the trails on the Washington side) and from west to east (heading away from Portland towards Hood River and beyond).Â

At the very bottom, youâll find a map of the trailheads for each of these hikes so you can visualize where they are.

Youâll start your hike at the small (so get there early!) parking lot right off of the Historic Columbia River Highway with a view of the lower falls from above. Then, itâs a short hike up to the upper falls, which is a two-tiered waterfall that tumbles into the creek below.

From there, youâll complete the loop, circling back around to approach the lower falls from below, which is even more magical than the view from above. Itâs a 224 foot plunge, and itâs an impressive sight.

In the winter and spring, a vibrant yellow moss covers the rocks around the falls, making for particularly good pictures when you combine it with the high flow rate thanks to the rain and snowmelt.

Itâs a two-tiered, 120 foot tall waterfall, which is nothing to sneeze at, even out here in the Gorge! You can clearly see both tiers, too, which is fairly unique in the Gorge.

Some people scramble down to the base of the falls along an unofficial trail, but we wouldnât recommend it (especially if itâs wet).

Well, Angelâs Rest is one of those hikes, and itâs a very popular one.

The parking lot here is tiny, though there is a small overflow lot nearby. Youâll want to get here before 9am on weekends to get a spot in the lot.

To be completely honest, thereâs nothing particularly special about the climb up to Angelâs Rest, which is a bald spot on the ridge with nice views up and down the Gorge. Itâs a steady climb all the way from beginning to end.

The landscape starts forested, and slowly becomes more rocky as you approach the top. Thereâs a waterfall along the way, but itâs nothing particularly impressive when compared to the countless other waterfalls nearby.

The last section of this hike is a set of rocky switchbacks, but itâs nothing past moderate difficulty.

Once you get to the top, the views of the Gorge in both directions are great.

In fact, weâd say theyâre among some of the nicest Gorge views on the Oregon side. The top of the hike puts you atop the bluff overlooking the Gorge, and there are a few different viewpoints up there.Â

Multnomah Falls is impressive and definitely worth seeing, but weâd do it first thing in the morning (before 9am, even earlier if you can swing it) and then move onto a different hike.

Itâs also worth noting that we didnât include the standalone hike up to the top of Multnomah Falls in this guide because, well, itâs just not really that cool in our honest assessment.Â

However, if you absolutely MUST hike at Multnomah Falls, weâd do this nifty little loop that takes you up to the top of Multnomah Falls (again, not that cool), back up through the forest passing a couple of cool waterfalls and plenty of fern-laden forest (this is cool), and along a ridge above the falls before descending past a couple more waterfalls, most notably Wahkeena Falls.Â

The hike starts at a small trailhead with no bathroom (and only room for 5-8 cars), and begins with a gentle climb that takes you up to the mouth of the Oneonta Gorge. From there, you stay high on the wall, following the creek up to Triple Falls.

Along the way, there are a couple of steep, rocky sections of climbing, and the trail is fairly narrow at times. Itâs definitely not hard or dangerous, but it was a little surprising, at least to us.

Eventually, you arrive at Triple Falls, which youâre looking down at from across the creek. You can continue around the back of the falls to the wooden footbridge which keeps going up the Oneonta Gorge, but the views werenât particularly great from there (we were hoping weâd get a better view down the Gorge).

Is it the most spectacular waterfall in the Columbia River Gorge? No. Is it a good alternative to being swamped with people at Multnomah or Latourell? Sure!

If youâre looking for an easy waterfall hike that toes the line between business/popularity and beauty of the waterfall, weâd put this up there with Wahclella Falls and Dry Creek Falls. And weâd slightly prefer both of those options over this hike, if weâre being honest.Â Â

There is a nice little add-on that you can do, which will take you over to Ponytail Falls (more on that in a second), which IS one of our favorite waterfalls in the Gorge.

At almost exactly one mile into the hike, the trail forks and the left fork veers off to a wooden footbridge over the creek, and continues up the hillside on the other side, eventually ending at Ponytail Falls, which is fun because you can walk behind it.

It will add about 1.5 miles round trip to the hike.

We wish there was a loop, but the only way to make it a loop involves walking along the narrow Historic Columbia River Highway, which doesnât seem like a good idea to us.

That, of course, means that itâs a popular spot, and youâll likely be fighting over parking spots in the relatively small lot (10-15 cars or so, no overflow along the road) if you visit over a weekend.

The first of the two waterfalls here is Horsetail Falls, and it is quite a sight to kick off the beginning of the hike.

Named, at least partially, for the type of waterfall (a horsetail waterfall looks kind of like, well, a horseâs tail if you squint a little bit), it tumbles 176 feet off of a ledge into the pool below.

From there, youâll head left and immediately start climbing a set of switchbacks, gaining most of the elevation in the first quarter mile of the trail.

The switchbacks end, putting you on a ridge with some peek-a-boo views across the Columbia River to the Washington side of the Gorge. Itâs a short walk along the ridge to Ponytail Falls, which is the final destination on this short Columbia River Gorge hike.

Ponytail Falls is equally scenic to the first waterfall on the trail. Itâs smaller, yes, clocking in at just 75 feet, but the cool part about this particular waterfall in the Columbia River Gorge is that you can walk behind it!

And not in a âif youâre willing to go off-trail and do some scramblingâ kind of way â the trail literally goes behind the falls.

Overall, a nice, easy hike for most levels, and a good option as a second hike in the Gorge after doing one of the harder ones earlier in the day.

Plus, itâs far enough from Portland that most of the crowds stop at Multnomah, and never make it this far east. That said, itâs a tiny parking lot (there is parking along the road), so be prepared to wait.

The trail is a lollipop, splitting about 0.6 miles into the hike. One side of the lollipop heads down to the level of Tanner Creek, crossing the creek over an elevated wooden bridge. The other side stays high, skirting the wall of the mini-gorge.

Both take you to the falls, and weâd head down first because it gives you a nice view of the falls as you make your way up the creek (we donât really have a strong opinion, though).

The waterfall itself is a two-tiered plunge 120 feet high, though you can barely see the second tier of the falls from the trail.

However, it is also very exposed in places, and youâll want to be prepared for the heat with plenty of water and sunscreen.Â

Third of all, there are a couple of steep, rocky sections that you traverse using cables. This is not great for dogs or small children, though it doesnât look too bad to Matt (who isnât a fan of heights).

The parking lot is small, and there is an overflow lot closer to the highway if itâs full when you arrive (though it does add a little bit of distance to the hike).

Youâll start by following Eagle Creek for a mile with limited elevation gain. From there, the trail starts its ascent, with a couple of steep rocky climbs on your way to Punchbowl Falls.

If youâre up for more hiking, you can follow the Eagle Creek Trail onwards to Tunnel Falls (13.5 miles round trip), which is a long, hard hike, but passes numerous waterfalls on the way to Tunnel Falls, which is one of the best in the Gorge.

Youâll start from the Bridge of the Gods Trailhead in Cascade Locks, which is a small lot with a bathroom.

Thereâs an alternate lot on Harvey Road (here on Google Maps) right next to the actual trailhead, which is just a gravel strip with a few more parking spots.Â

Youâll follow a section of the Pacific Crest Trail for the vast majority of this hike, with a short stint on the Dry Creek Falls trail at the very end. Itâs a very gradual ascent that you hardly even notice.

The one thing you will notice, however, is the damage to the trees wrought by the 2017 Eagle Creek Fire (are you noticing a theme here? It was a huge deal).Â

Dry Creek Falls itself is not the tallest waterfall out here, but it is a nice reward for a relatively low effort. Itâs 74 feet high, and itâs particularly cool in the winter and early spring when itâs both rushing, and the rocks are covered in a bright green or yellow moss.

One of the coolest parts about the falls is actually the history associated with it.

You can see the remnants of a water diversion system from nearly a century ago at the base of the falls, which was used to provide drinking water to residents nearby. This caused the creek below the diversion to run dry, hence the name.Â

The parking lot for this hike is along the Historic Columbia River Highway, just east of the town of Mosier. Thereâs very limited parking at the Memaloose Overlook, which is essentially a dirt pullout off the road, with no bathroom at the trailhead.

Thereâs a small network of trails here that forms a figure eight, with the two hills â Chatfield and Marsh â as the focal points of either side of the adjoining loops.

Itâs worth doing the entirety of the perimeter trail, taking in both summits (and more importantly, the wildflower blanketed slopes of the hills).

There are also some nice views of both Mount Hood and the Columbia River Gorge, particularly from Chatfield Hill and its southern slope.

Make sure to check yourself and your dog for ticks after the hike! They like to hang out in the tall grasses along the trail.

There are two specific viewpoints along this trail â the main viewpoint at 1.3 miles in, and the Windblown Fir viewpoint at the 3.7 mile mark (which makes a good turnaround point when the loop is closed â more on that below).

To be completely honest, this isnât our favorite of the hikes out here, but it is the closest to the Portland / Vancouver area, and there are some nice views to be had.

Itâs just that, in between those two views, thereâs not much interesting scenery happening. ESPECIALLY if you canât do the loop that takes you down along the cliffs. We donât really even consider this hike unless the full loop is open, which is usually from July through February.

The trail starts with an aggressive set of switchbacks, climbing to the highest point of the trail (and one of the best views) at 1.3 miles in.

If youâre doing the loop, itâs all downhill from thereâ¦at least until the last mile and a half or so, where itâs a slow, steady incline back to the parking lot (if the loop is closed, itâs a steady climb back up, then a steep descent back to the parking lot).

The parking lot here is relatively big when compared to a lot of the hikes in the Gorge, but it still fills up somewhere between 9am and 10am on most summer weekends.

A note here: The lower section of this trail is closed annually for peregrine falcon nesting between February and July. You can still do the hike, but you wonât be able to do the lower section of the loop that skirts the cliffs. You have to make it an out and back, which makes it slightly longer.

Itâs not an easy climb by any means, but itâs doable for most people as evidenced by the numerous children youâll probably encounter on the way up.

Be warned â this is not a particularly easy hike. We just mentioned kids, and itâs worth noting that we saw multiple kids in various states of meltdown on the way up.Â

This is probably not a destination in and of itself, but itâs a nice compliment to some of the other hikes on this list. Weâd make sure to do it as early as possible, since it does get crowded and itâs a very narrow trail where itâs easy to get trapped behind other people.

The trailhead is inside Beacon Rock State Park, and the lot is big and there are nice flush toilets at the trailhead.

Some people do this as an out and back up to the summit, but we think you should do the lollipop trail, if you can, so that you make it up to the saddle, which is our favorite view of the hike.

Tackle the loop portion counter clockwise, heading up the Hamilton Mountain Trail to Little Hamilton Mountain (one of the better views on the hike) and climbing the aggressive switchbacks to the summit.

At the summit, prepare to be disappointed because there are no views to be had, but continue on to the saddle for a spectacular view of Hamilton Mountain and the Gorge beyond.

On the way down, itâs a more gradual descent down through the forest, which is part of the reason weâd recommend going this direction (aggressive descents are no fun).

However, it is also worth noting that it also happens to be one of the hardest of the hikes in this guide, so youâll want to make sure youâre prepared with plenty of water, food, sun protection, and fitness.

The reason this trail is so popular is that, during the spring (May, ish), Dog Mountain puts on a SHOW of wildflowers.

Itâs such a popular place for wildflower spotting that they had to introduce a permit system on weekends during peak wildflower season to reduce congestion â more information here.Â

If youâre coming on a weekend (or a holiday Monday) in the spring (April through June), youâll need to plan in advance and secure a permit before your hike. If theyâre sold out for your date, they do hold 100 permits that are released three days in advance at 7am PST.

You need to print out your permit and have a physical copy to show rangers, otherwise you will get a ticket.

With those logistics out of the way, letâs talk about the hike.

The first thing we want to say â and this might be a controversial take, but we stand by it â is that Dog Mountain is probably the worst effort:pleasure ratio of the popular wildflower hikes in the Gorge. Weâd rank Coyote Wall, Memaloose Hills, and Tom McCall Point above Dog Mountain in terms of that ratio.

That certainly doesnât mean Dog Mountain isnât spectacular â it has some of the best Gorge views AND wildflowers on the Washington side of the Gorge â but you have to do 3,000 feet of climbing over three miles to get them.

We usually say anywhere from 600-800 feet of elevation gain per mile is tough, and this is up at 1,000 feet of elevation gain per mile on the climb up.

This is a very tough hike, donât underestimate it. You need more than 1 liter of water per person, and a few snacks for the climb up. Plus sun protection, extra food and water for dogs, and a base level of fitness.

There are a couple of routes you can go. Weâre always going to choose a loop trail over an out and back to change up the scenery, and Dog Mountain is no different.

We prefer more aggressive climbs and more gradual descents to save our knees, so weâd do this hike counterclockwise, heading up to the right, and coming down the left side of the loop.

Plus, there are a couple of good viewpoints on the way up if you take the âharderâ route up, which make a nice place to rest and grab a drink of water as you climb.

Parking here is right off of Highway 14 on the Washington side of the Gorge, about 12 miles west of Bingen/White Salmon, and 54 miles east of Vancouver, WA. Parking is competitive, and is usually full by 9am or so on weekends in the spring (reminder to secure your permit!).

There are restrooms at the trailhead and, crucially, there is no overflow parking lot here.

If you want to avoid the parking situation on weekends and take public transportation, we have some great news. There is a shuttle from Hood River run by CAT that stops at the Skamania County Fairgrounds (here on Google Maps) that takes you out to Dog Mountain.

The shuttle runs every 30 minutes (ish) from 7:30am to 5pm (last shuttle to Dog Mountain at 1pm, last shuttle leaving from Dog Mountain at 5pm). Best of all, itâs FREE and it includes a permit to hike the trail! No reservations required â first-come, first-served.

The trailhead has parking for 24 cars (we counted), along with a few other spots along the road just outside the parking lot. There is also a pit toilet at the trailhead, which is always helpful.

We didnât really realize how striking the geology here is until we were driving through Mosier on the Oregon side of the river the next morning, where you have a great view of the âwallâ across the river. Itâs basically a towering rocky spine that runs from the water level a few thousand feet up the wall of the Gorge.

You donât really get a chance to see the scale of the wall unless youâre looking at it from afar, though you do get some nice views of it from above.

The hike itself is moderate. Itâs a weird lollipop hike (weâd call it a reverse lollipop) where you have two options when it comes to ascending to the edge of the cliffs â one that is shorter, steeper, and rockier, one that is winding and more gradual.

Then, once you get up to the cliffs, the two routes meet up and you do an out and back section of the hike to the viewpoint at the end (where thereâs another small lollipop section).

The draw for this hike is definitely the wildflowers in the spring (May and early June, mostly). We did this hike the second week of May, and after we got up to the ridge, it was an incredible, neverending display of wildflowers like balsamroot and Lupine.

The only thing to know is that you do need to do some climbing to get to them, similar to Dog Mountain.

There are also some great views of the Gorge, especially to the east, as you climb, and once you are up on the cliffs, you are high enough that you get some good views of Mount Hood across the Gorge.

Outside of the spring (and fall), weâd probably choose a different hike. This hike is very, very exposed with little tree cover, and it would be excruciatingly hot in the summer. In the winter when it rains, Iâd imagine this hike is a mud bath.

Keep an eye out for rattlesnakes and ticks on this trail, especially in the spring and summer.

We did this on a spring afternoon, and were surprised at how much we enjoyed this hike.Â

Itâs not as spectacular as those two more popular hikes nearbyâ¦ but you donât need a permit to hike it, and you donât need to get into a fight to the death over parking.

The trailhead is right off of Highway 14 a few miles past the Coyote Wall Trailhead and past the tiny town of Lyle. Thereâs parking for 12-15 cars in the gravel lot, and there are no restrooms at the trailhead (so plan in advance!).

The hike is an out and back (or a small lollipop at the end) that takes you up a series of switchbacks to ascend to a ridge, which you then follow east out to a viewpoint with great views of the Gorge.

In the spring, there were some nice wildflowers (balsamroot and lupine, mostly), and we loved the views of the green hills of the Gorge in the spring.

Keep an eye out for rattlesnakes and ticks on this trail, especially in the spring and summer. Matt almost stepped on a rattlesnake on the trail because he was distracted by the wildflowers.

Itâs also worth noting that, in the spring, there was a ton of overgrown poison oak along the trail, particularly in the forested section at the bottom and along the ridge.
